pageContext.claim: “If you read the papers today, it came out to the surprise of a lot of people -- not a surprise to me -- that they [the North Koreans] don't mind having people come over, the experts, and check the sites.”
pageContext.analysis: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un agreed in an Oct. 7 meeting to allow inspectors into one nuclear testing site, Punggye-ri, which the North Koreans claimed to have blown up. However, there was no mention of a separate nuclear facility called Yongbyon, where the North Koreans have a reactor that produces plutonium, and where analysts have observed new activity based on satellite imagery since Trump met with Kim in Singapore this year. The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said in late November 2018 that activity had been observed at Yongbyon but “without access the agency cannot confirm the nature and purpose of these activities.”
